body: I'm not concerned and I think the best we can do is to cover all features with tests.
@slukyano I've updated code according to your suggestions. Thank you for your efforts. Is patch looking good now?

I absolutely agree with you, that features must be covered with the tests, and, as you can see, I already wrote a test for this feature. But my point is that writing both unit and component tests for the every code change is not right. Especially in this case.
Usually comments are named like "IGNITE-XXXX: My message...". Somebody can say that it's redundant information, but it's just a common practice.

Thank you for the PR

3. I propose to add 1 major test - the one that will tests output equality of old and new CRC calculation algorithm

4. Can you attach to ticket results of benchmarking:
  4.1 Comparsion of CRC calculation algorithms: Please, add JMH benchmark in your PR.
  4.2 Ignite regular yardstick tests with and without your improvement.
Would be nice if you could throw in some test that would pinpoint the problem, i.e., fail without fix but pass with it.

Hello, @stuartmacd 

Overall looks good.

1. Why we use `DEFAULT_DATABASE` as a default name in the External catalog?
If it schema name we should use default schema - `QueryUtils.DFLT_SCHEMA`.
Is it makes sense for you?

2. Let's add some tests for a new "change DB" in catalog feature.
The test should list all tables from one schema and then from another.

3. Should we add some warning or even throw an exception if the user tries to specify `OPTION_SCHEMA` in write mode? I propose to throw an exception in that case.
We need a test for that too.

Hi @rahulbsw,
Are you planning this PR to be merged? In Ignite development process each contribution should be related to a ticket in https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/IGNITE/issues Also a proper way to start review process is writing an email to dev mail list. See https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/IGNITE/issues
Also https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/IGNITE/How+to+Contribute is useful resource.

@nizhikov thanks for the review. Please find my follow-ups below.

> Why we use DEFAULT_DATABASE as a default name in the External catalog?
> If it schema name we should use default schema - QueryUtils.DFLT_SCHEMA.
> Is it makes sense for you?

We use `DEFAULT_DATABASE` as a signifier that by default we will search all schemas for the given table unless a schema other than `DEFAULT_DATABASE` has been specified. If we were to default to `PUBLIC` then we would only look for tables in that schema (or if we treated `PUBLIC` like we do `DEFAULT_DATABASE` then there would be no way for a caller to specifically ask for a table from `PUBLIC`). Let me know if that doesn't make sense.

> Let's add some tests for a new "change DB" in catalog feature.
> The test should list all tables from one schema and then from another.

Agreed - I have expanded my test in `IgniteCatalogSpec` to switch between two different databases.

> Should we add some warning or even throw an exception if the user tries to specify OPTION_SCHEMA in write mode? I propose to throw an exception in that case.
> We need a test for that too.

I think this should only be an error if we are creating a new table in non-PUBLIC schema; I have added a check and test for this. If we are in write mode and not creating the table or if we are creating a table and the schema has been specified as PUBLIC, this should be valid as far as I can see - do you agree?

> I think this should only be an error if we are creating a new table in non-PUBLIC schema

Yes. Thanks for the clarification.

> We use DEFAULT_DATABASE as a signifier that by default we will search all schemas for the given table unless a schema other than DEFAULT_DATABASE has been specified.

OK. I agree. 

I will make a review in a day.

Thank you, @stuartmacd !

@stuartmacd 

> We use DEFAULT_DATABASE as a signifier that by default we will search all schemas for the given table unless a schema other than DEFAULT_DATABASE has been specified.

I thought more about your proposal.
What if a user wants to browse tables from schema `"default"` which is equal to constant `DEFAULT_DATABASE`. Looks like we should use an empty string to denote "all schemas" case.

What do you think?

@stuartmacd Overall looks very good.
Let's come to a consensus with the default database name.

Just a friendly reminder: October 10 is code freeze date for a 2.7 release. 
Please, ping me when you address my comments.
Please, resolve conflicts with master.

@nizhikov thanks for continuing the review. I don't think we have a lot of option with the `DEFAULT_DATABASE` naming, as it is used internally by Spark whenever you do not specify the name of the schema in Spark SQL. Ie. you can run the first test case in `IgniteCatalogSpec` and see that Spark passes `default` as the schema name through to the `listTables()` operation - so I believe this is a Spark limitation as I'm not aware of any way to change the value of `DEFAULT_DATABASE`.

@avplatonov 
Thank you for the review. You are right that this implementation only for continuous feature values. 
But this PR is already big enough. That's why as it was discussed in dev-list 
[e-mail](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/da1a2f7bf528d0801ecb7decaf2b640393b7cd2ca69de00ef4feb281@%3Cdev.ignite.apache.org%3E)
I created separate tasks for other types of Bayes classifier. I.e. [Multinomial](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IGNITE-9745) works with discrete features.
I'm going to continue implementing other classifiers as separate tasks/PRs.

You mentioned `meta-information` in your comment. To be honest, I have no idea how to use this implementation with discrete features. But if have any ideas on how to improve this solution let me know.

Hi, @dehasi. Regarding this PR the most important concern I have is using of `LabeledDatasetPartitionDataBuilderOnHeap` instead of custom data builder based on `GaussianNaiveBayesSumsHolder`. Current implementation requires O(n) additional memory while the algorithm itself doesn't. Could you please have a look at this problem?

@dmitrievanthony 

I replaced `Dataset<EmptyContext, LabeledDatasetPartitionDataBuilderOnHeap >` to `Dataset<EmptyContext, GaussianNaiveBayesSumsHolder>`. Could you take a look?

Hi!

It seems that the LLPL is not productized at all: no releases, no Maven, no docs. 

In Apache Ignite we add dependencies using Maven. I don't think it makes sense to proceed with this PR until we have the binary release of LLPL in Maven available.
I checked this fix: code diffs look right and involved tests don't fail anymore (these failed prior to fix)

It seems ready to merge to the Ignite, @ybabak please have a look

Hi -
I am an Ignite user from China,  I do not recommend that you add Taiwan and Hong Kong to the countries list.
Because this is a sensitive political topic for the Chinese, and almost all countries that have established diplomatic relations with China recognize that Taiwan and Hong Kong are inseparable parts of China.

If you want to add them to the countries list, I suggest that you change the label name(the place where display those areas) from **_Country_** to **_Country/Region_** , since this will avoid these problems.

Xiaolan Ji

I really like how zk-related tests are split from a huge class into a separate classes each testing specific aspects of functionality.

But I have a suggestion about naming of new ZookeeperDiscovery test classes. What if we include a name of major functionality covered by each class?

I would suggest the following changes:
- ZookeeperDiscoverySpiTest -> ZookeeperDiscoveryMiscTest
- Test2 -> SegmentationAndConnectionRestoreTest
- Test3 -> ConcurrectStartAndStartStopTest
- Test4 -> TopologyChangeAndReconnectTest
- Test5 -> CommunicationFailureTest
- Test6 -> ClientDisconnectTest
- Test7 -> SplitBrainTest
- Test8 -> CustomEventsTest

Hello @igor-suhorukov 
Thanks for the patch!
There are several issues that has to be resolved prior merge:

1. Please, edit PR description. Use format IGNITE-XXXX: Ticket description.
Where: "IGNITE-XXXX" is the Jira ticket you trying to resolve with this patch.
"Ticket description" = Replace explicit generic type with diamond operator

2. Please, resolve conflicts with master

3. You should edit `~/src/ignite/idea/ignite_codeStyle.xml`, `~/src/ignite/idea/ignite_inspections_teamcity.xml` to enable corresponding inspection. So we would check future patches with it.

`IgniteH2BaseLocalResult` is a slightly modified copy of [`org.h2.result.LocalResultImpl`](https://github.com/h2database/h2database/blob/master/h2/src/main/org/h2/result/LocalResultImpl.java) that was written by multiple authors and is dual-licensed under MPL 2.0 and EPL 1.0. (See also history of [`LocalResult`](https://github.com/h2database/h2database/blob/master/h2/src/main/org/h2/result/LocalResult.java) that was renamed to `LocalResultImpl` earlier and replaced with an interface.)

Your copy is licenced under Apache License 2.0 and does not contain original copyright headers.

I think you need either to preserve original licence and copyright headers (MPL 2.0 is more or less compatible with Apache License), or rewrite this class from the scratch, or inherit it and override methods that you want to change without copying large pieces of code.
